newsitem.title: REPUBLIC OF IRELAND: Irish pub owners demand looser closing hours.
newsitem.headline: Irish pub owners demand looser closing hours.

text.p: Ireland's pubs, for years the headquarters of a quirky national anarchy, pressed parliament on Tuesday to be allowed to choose their own closing hours.
The Chambers of Commerce, the mouthpiece of shops and businesses, told parliament market forces rather than age-old laws should govern when the nation's 30,000 pubs should be open.
"The Chambers are delighted to note that parliament is taking a serious look at the issue of reform of our licensing laws," chief executive Paul Skehan told a parliament committee.

At present pubs are open around 12 hours a day but usually close at midnight. On Sundays they observe what is called "holy hour," a two-hour closure said to be enforced to allow people to attend Mass.

But closing hours are often flouted. Many pub owners simply lock the doors with the drinkers still inside and pretend to be closed, a practice which is especially hard to police in far-flung rural areas.
Parliament is studying changing the laws after pub owners and some parliamentarians complained that closing hours were anachronistic and puzzled tourists, a key source of revenue.
